TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .

CARDINAL . The applicant receives an old - age pension . The PERSON of DATE on the Calculation and Upgrading of State Pensions ( “ the Pensions Act ” ) introduced , from CARDINAL DATE , a new method for calculating pensions . The idea behind this method , based on what is known as an “ individual pensioner coefficient ” , was to link the pension to the pensioner 's previous earnings .

CARDINAL . The authority in charge of the applicant 's pension , ORG of LOC of GPE ( “ the Agency ” ) , fixed the applicant 's coefficient at CARDINAL . The applicant challenged the ORG 's decision in ORG . She argued that her coefficient should be TIME .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG found for the applicant , considering that the ORG had misinterpreted LAW . In particular , it held as follows :

“ ... DATE [ of LAW ] fixes an individual pensioner coefficient at the maximum rate of CARDINAL . This rate is subject to changes hereafter by a federal law at the adoption of a federal law on the budget of the ORG PF [ ORG ] for DATE . ”
ORG decided that the ORG was to recalculate the applicant 's pension using a coefficient of PERCENT from DATE “ until a change in the legislation ” .
CARDINAL . The ORG appealed against the judgment . On DATE ORG upheld the judgment , which became enforceable on DATE . The judgment was never executed .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( “ the Ministry ” ) issued an Instruction on the “ Application of Limitations ” established by LAW ( “ the Instruction ” ) . The LAW clarified how to apply LAW .

CARDINAL . NORP On DATE the ORG lodged an application with ORG for the reconsideration of the applicant 's case owing to newly discovered circumstances . They asked the court to take account of the ORG , which supported their arguments that had been rejected by the court during the initial examination of the case .

CARDINAL . Some time thereafter a group of individuals challenged the ORG before ORG of GPE . On DATE ORG dismissed the complaint . It found that , contrary to what the complainants had suggested , ORG had not acted ultra vires in issuing the ORG , and that the ORG 's interpretation of LAW had been correct . On DATE ORG upheld this judgment on appeal .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG examined the ORG 's request . ORG noted that by virtue of LAW enforceable judgments may be reconsidered owing to newly discovered circumstances which could not have been known at the time when the judgment had been delivered . The court further noted that the ORG had been upheld by ORG which , therefore , had found it lawful to interpret article CARDINAL of LAW so that the rate of PERSON should not apply to an “ individual pensioner coefficient ” .

CARDINAL . In a decision of DATE ORG granted the ORG 's application , under LAW , quashed the judgment of DATE , as upheld on DATE , and ordered a fresh examination of the case . It stated that its decision was not subject to appeal .

CARDINAL . As a result of the fresh examination of the case ORG delivered a judgment of DATE in which it rejected the applicant 's claims in full . The applicant appealed . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant 's appeal and upheld the judgment of DATE .
CARDINAL . From DATE , following changes to the pension regulations , the applicant 's pension was calculated based on a coefficient of CARDINAL .
CARDINAL . The Code of Civil Procedure of DATE ( “ CCivP ” ) , in force at the material time , provided as follows :
“ [ Judgments ] which have come into force may be reconsidered on the basis of newly discovered circumstances . The grounds for reconsideration ... shall be as follows :
CARDINAL . significant circumstances which were not and could not have been known to the party who applies for reconsideration ; ...
CARDINAL . cancellation of a court [ judgment ] or of another authority 's decision which served as legal basis for the [ judgment ] in question . ”
“ ... [ An application for reconsideration of a [ judgment ] owing to newly discovered circumstances ] shall be lodged within DATE after the discovery of the circumstances . ”

“ After examination of an application for reconsideration of a [ judgment ] owing to newly discovered circumstances , the court may either grant the application and quash the [ judgment ] , or dismiss the application .
The court decision by which an application for reconsideration of a [ judgment ] owing to newly discovered circumstances is granted shall not be subject to appeal . ... ”

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of GPE adopted a ruling concerning certain provisions of LAW ( “ CCrP ” ) . In that ruling ORG decided that LAW CCrP ( “ FAC for reconsideration of a [ criminal ] case on the basis of newly discovered circumstances ” , which was in many respects similar to LAW was unconstitutional in that it limited the grounds for the reopening of a criminal case to situations of “ newly discovered circumstances ” . In that ruling ORG suggested that this provision of the ORG prevented rectification of judicial errors and miscarriages of justice . In its ruling of CARDINAL DATE ORG came to the conclusion that LAW was unconstitutional in so far as it had served as a basis for the dismissal of applications for reconsideration of judgments of the Presidium of ORG , where the judgment had been delivered as a result of a judicial error which had not been and could not have been established earlier .

CARDINAL . The Instruction of the Ministry of Labour and Social Development of DATE on the “ Application of Limitations ” established by LAW was registered by ORG on DATE and became binding in DATE , DATE after its official publication .
